elements.content: Five novel Zn(II)/Cd(II)-based coordination polymers 1–5 with a flexible disulfide derivative of the nicotinate 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid (H2cpds) and two rodlike N,N′-donor ligands (bpa =1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane; bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) have been successfully synthesized under the liquid diffusion condition and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra, and X-ray diffraction, namely {[Zn(cpds)]·H2O} n (1), {[Zn(cpds)(bpa)0.5]} n (2), {[Zn(cpds)(bpp)]} n (3), {[Cd(cpds)(bpa)1.5]·H2O} n (4), and {[Cd2(cpds)2(bpp)·(H2O)3]·4H2O} n (5). Complexes 1–5 display various coordination motifs due to different conformations, and coordination modes of the H2cpds ligand, at the same time the effect of the auxiliary ligands plays important roles in the construction of extended supramolecular networks. Complexes 2–4 all exhibit 2D layer structures, in which 2 displays a 2-fold 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration framework containing a rotaxane-like motif and 3 is a 2D 44 gridlike layer. Compound 4 contains two kinds of 2D chiral layers composed of three types of single-helical chains and two types of double-stranded helices. Two high-dimensional complexes (3D) with a microporous network containing a 1D metal–organic nanotube filled with plenty of free water molecules for 1, and a 3-fold interpenetrating network with (46·64) topology by considering the cadmium dimer unit as a five-connected node for 5, are observed. Solid-state properties of thermal stability, X-ray powder diffractions, and the photoluminescence properties at room temperature for these crystalline materials have been investigated.

elements.content: The present work demonstrates the promising opportunities of the combined effect of the flexible carboxylate-and-pyridyl mixed ligands that are the flexible disulfide derivative of carboxylate ligand 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid (H2cpds) and two flexible rodlike N,N′-donor ligands (bpa =1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane; bpp =1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) with different numbers of methylene groups between the two 4-pyridyl rings in presenting Zn(II)/Cd(II) metals to generate five novel compounds. The structure differences among 1−5 highlight the effects of the bonding modes and the conformations of cpds ligand on the framework of complexes; at the same time the effect of the auxiliary ligands plays important roles in the construction of extend supramolecular networks. In addition, thermogravimetric analyses, X-ray powder diffractions, and the photoluminescence properties at room temperature of complexes 1−5 have been investigated.

elements.content: The currently progressive impetus for the design and fabrication of novel metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is rooted not only in their fascinating topological structures but also from their promising properties and great potential applications in the fields of gas storage, magnetism, and optical properties, and so on. It has been observed that organic ligands play crucial roles for the designed synthesis of some interesting coordination networks, such as the donating type, the flexibility, and the geometry of the organic ligands. Among various organic ligands, polycarboxyl compounds have been extensively used as multifunctional tectons, due to their extension ability both in covalent bonding and in supramolecular interactions (H-bonding and aromatic stacking). Recent studies have proved that the rigid aromatic multicarboxylates are effective ligands to bridge metal nodes into a variety of interesting open metal–organic networks with various cavity dimensions and shapes for potential applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The currently progressive impetus for the design and fabrication of novel metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is rooted not only in their fascinating topological structures but also from their promising properties and great potential applications in the fields of gas storage, magnetism, and optical properties, and so on. It has been observed that organic ligands play crucial roles for the designed synthesis of some interesting coordination networks, such as the donating type, the flexibility, and the geometry of the organic ligands. Among various organic ligands, polycarboxyl compounds have been extensively used as multifunctional tectons, due to their extension ability both in covalent bonding and in supramolecular interactions (H-bonding and aromatic stacking). Recent studies have proved that the rigid aromatic multicarboxylates are effective ligands to bridge metal nodes into a variety of interesting open metal-organic networks with various cavity dimensions and shapes for potential applications.

elements.content: However, in contrast to rigid carboxylates, the coordination networks constructed from flexible carboxylates are relatively underdeveloped. It is difficult to predict either the composition or the network topology constructed from a flexible carboxylate due to the conformational freedom in the assembly process. However, the special conformation and coordination functionality of the flexible ligand might generate some unprecedented coordination frameworks. In this regard, flexible disulfide derivatives bearing −S–S– spacers have attracted considerable interest, because they can afford more rich structure information compared with rigid ligands. In addition, not only do such disulfide derivatives act as the organic bridging “spacer” to create interesting topology structures when combined with metal ions, but also the facile cleavage of the central S–S bond can result in diversiform in situ ligand reactions under different reaction conditions. Nevertheless, it is still a challenge to predict and control the ligand reactions toward our target products, and more knowledge of this field is needed. In this report, we focused our attention on utilizing a flexible disulfide derivative of the carboxylate ligand 6,6′-dithiodinicotinic acid (H2cpds) adopting a twist conformation with a C–S–S–C torsion angle of ca. 90° which can show the axial chirality with the M- and P-forms of the enantiomers to construct interesting coordination frameworks. Moreover, H2cpds not only has hard-only (carboxylate-O) but also has soft-only (pyridine-N) donor sets presenting versatile coordination modes to connect metal ions into higher-dimensional structures.

However, the special conformation and coordination functionality of the flexible ligand might generate some unprecedented coordination frameworks. In this regard, flexible disulfide derivatives bearing -S-S- spacers have attracted considerable interest, because they can afford more rich structure information compared with rigid ligands. In addition, not only do such disulfide derivatives act as the organic bridging "spacer" to create interesting topology structures when combined with metal ions, but also the facile cleavage of the central S-S bond can result in diversiform in situ ligand reactions under different reaction conditions. Nevertheless, it is still a challenge to predict and control the ligand reactions toward our target products, and more knowledge of this field is needed. In this report, we focused our attention on utilizing a flexible disulfide derivative of the carboxylate ligand 6,6'-dithiodinicotinic acid (H2cpds) adopting a twist conformation with a C-S-S-C torsion angle of ca. 90° which can show the axial chirality with the M- and P-forms of the enantiomers to construct interesting coordination frameworks. Moreover, H2cpds not only has hard-only (carboxylate-O) but also has soft-only (pyridine-N) donor sets presenting versatile coordination modes to connect metal ions into higher-dimensional structures.

elements.content: On the other hand, the introduction of additional N-donor ligands to the synthetic systems is of great potential to construct higher-dimensional supramolecular networks and novel topology. Rodlike N,N′-donor organic linkers have been extensively studied and modified by introducing spacers between the two 4-pyridyl groups with variable flexibility and functionality, which can result in distinct spatial effects to produce unexpected architectures upon metal–carboxylate complexes. In our previous work, we have introduced the rigid additional N-donor ligands into the M-cpds system to bring on fascinating architectures. However, the combined effect of the flexible carboxylate-and-pyridyl mixed ligands has been less exploited in the construction of coordination polymers. As a continuation of our previous work, two flexible rodlike N,N′-donor ligands (bpa = 1,2-bi(4-pyridyl)ethane; bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane) with different numbers of methylene groups between the two 4-pyridyl rings are introduced into the synthetic systems. Herein we report five novel coordination polymers with mixed ligands H2cpds-bpa/bpp and Zn(II)/Cd(II) metals under the liquid diffusion conditions, {[Zn(cpds)]·H2O} n (1), {[Zn(cpds)(bpa)0.5]} n (2), {[Zn(cpds)(bpp)]} n (3), {[Cd(cpds)(bpa)1.5]·H2O} n (4), and {[Cd2(cpds)2(bpp)·(H2O)3]·4H2O} n (5), respectively. The syntheses, structure analyses, thermal stabilities, X-ray powder diffractions, and photoluminescence properties of five complexes have been studied.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were recorded on a Perkin–Elmer model 240C instrument. Infrared spectra were performed on KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrophotometer in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Thermal analysis was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1 under a N2 atmosphere. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were investigated with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern was recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All chemicals purchased were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer model 240C instrument. Infrared spectra were performed on KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrophotometer in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Thermal analysis was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 under a N2 atmosphere. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were investigated with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The X-ray powder diffraction pattern was recorded with a Rigaku D/Max 3III diffractometer.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of the five compounds were carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer, equipped with a graphite monochromator using Mo Κα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), by using a ϕ/ω scan technique at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and successive Fourier difference synthesis (SHELXS-97), and they were refined using the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms (SHELXL-97). The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1–5 are listed in Tables and S1. Possible hydrogen bond geometries of partial complexes are listed in Table S2 ().
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses of the five compounds were carried out on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer, equipped with a graphite monochromator using Mo Κα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), by using a ϕ/ω scan technique at room temperature. The structures were solved using direct methods and successive Fourier difference synthesis (SHELXS-97), and they were refined using the full-matrix least-squares method on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms (SHELXL-97). The crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for 1-5 are listed in Tables  and S1. Possible hydrogen bond geometries of partial complexes are listed in Table S2 ().

The mixing of the starting materials results in precipitation in traditional aqueous reactions, making it difficult to grow crystals of complexes. So, in order to obtain crystals, suitable for X-ray analysis, the liquid diffusion methods were applied. Under the liquid diffusion condition, the −S–S– spacer of cpds ligand is stable. Generally, the in situ cleavage of the S–S bond might occur in the solvothermal reactions. For the title complexes, we used inorganic NaOH with molar ratio 2:1 to the H2cpds to ensure complete deprotonation of H2cpds, and the pH value of the final solution is about 7. 1–5 are air stable with the maintenance of their crystallinity for at least some weeks and are insoluble in common organic solvents and water, being consistent with their polymeric and neutral nature. Compound 1 (Zn/cpds) was obtained without auxiliary ligand; however, Cd/cpds complex is not succeeded suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis in the liquid diffusion condition. Complexes 2–5 were uniformly obtained by the introduction of flexible rodlike N-containing auxiliary ligand (bpp, bpa). Probably, the two flexible N-containing ligands with different numbers of methylene groups between the two 4-pyridyl rings can freely rotate to meet the requirement of metal ions coordination geometries during the structure assembly process. The syntheses were summarized in Scheme .

Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The mixing of the starting materials results in precipitation in traditional aqueous reactions, making it difficult to grow crystals of complexes. So, in order to obtain crystals, suitable for X-ray analysis, the liquid diffusion methods were applied. Under the liquid diffusion condition, the -S-S- spacer of cpds ligand is stable. Generally, the in situ cleavage of the S-S bond might occur in the solvothermal reactions. For the title complexes, we used inorganic NaOH with molar ratio 2:1 to the H2cpds to ensure complete deprotonation of H2cpds, and the pH value of the final solution is about 7. 1-5 are air stable with the maintenance of their crystallinity for at least some weeks and are insoluble in common organic solvents and water, being consistent with their polymeric and neutral nature. Compound 1 (Zn/cpds) was obtained without auxiliary ligand; however, Cd/cpds complex is not succeeded suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis in the liquid diffusion condition. Complexes 2-5 were uniformly obtained by the introduction of flexible rodlike N-containing auxiliary ligand (bpp, bpa). Probably, the two flexible N-containing ligands with different numbers of methylene groups between the two 4-pyridyl rings can freely rotate to meet the requirement of metal ions coordination geometries during the structure assembly process. The syntheses were summarized in Scheme .

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Procedures of the Title Complexes 1-5

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) atom, one cpds ligand, and one lattice water, as shown in Figure a. The environment around the Zn(II) atom can be described as a distorted square-pyramidal geometry, and it is coordinated by four oxygen atoms of four cpds ligands in an equator plane and one nitrogen atom from cpds ligand occupying the axial position. The Zn–N bond length is 2.080(5) Å, and the Zn–O distances are in the range 2.017(6)–2.064(5) Å. Noticeably, the cpds ligand is here not only a simple multicarboxylate ligand, but also it can also afford an N atom to bond the metals, which is first observed in M–cpds complexes. Two Zn(II) atoms are bridged by four carboxylates in a bridging bis(bidentate) fashion to give a paddle-wheel shaped unit with the Zn···Zn distance of 3.009(2) Å. The bimetallic Zn(II) units are linked by the cpds to form a 1D loop chain, in which cpds ligands first connect Zn(II) atoms to form a [Zn4(cpds)2] metallocyclic motif (Figure b). Further, these 1D loop chains are cross-linked by the connection of a Zn–N bond acting as a bridging linker to give birth to a 3D framework (Figure c). It is worth noting that the [Zn4(cpds)2] subunits are infinitely connected by Zn–N bonds along the c axis to give rise to a 1D metal–organic nanotube (MONT) in the 3D framework with dimensions of 12.837 × 12.317 Å2 (Figure d), filled by plenty of free water molecules (Figure e). After the removal of free guest solvents, the volume of the effective void, calculated using PLATON, is 26.0% of the unit-cell volume. In complex 1, H2cpds adopts a V-shaped conformation, and the angle between the two carboxylate groups is ca. 90° and can be used effectively for the construction of a polygonal subunit, which enhances the possibility of the formation of a nanotubular framework. From the analyses of the topology network using TOPOS, taking the bimetallic Zn(II) units as 6-connected nodes and the cpds ligands as 3-connected nodes, the 3D structure of compound 1 can be described as a binodal (3,6)-connected network with the Point symbol of (42·6)2(44·62·87·102) (Figure f).

Structural Description of 1-5 

{[Zn(cpds)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) atom, one cpds ligand, and one lattice water, as shown in Figure a. The environment around the Zn(II) atom can be described as a distorted square-pyramidal geometry, and it is coordinated by four oxygen atoms of four cpds ligands in an equator plane and one nitrogen atom from cpds ligand occupying the axial position. The Zn-N bond length is 2.080(5) Å, and the Zn-O distances are in the range 2.017(6)-2.064(5) Å. Noticeably, the cpds ligand is here not only a simple multicarboxylate ligand, but also it can also afford an N atom to bond the metals, which is first observed in M-cpds complexes. Two Zn(II) atoms are bridged by four carboxylates in a bridging bis(bidentate) fashion to give a paddle-wheel shaped unit with the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance of 3.009(2) Å. The bimetallic Zn(II) units are linked by the cpds to form a 1D loop chain, in which cpds ligands first connect Zn(II) atoms to form a [Zn4(cpds)2] metallocyclic motif (Figure b). Further, these 1D loop chains are cross-linked by the connection of a Zn-N bond acting as a bridging linker to give birth to a 3D framework (Figure c). It is worth noting that the [Zn4(cpds)2] subunits are infinitely connected by Zn-N bonds along the c axis to give rise to a 1D metal-organic nanotube (MONT) in the 3D framework with dimensions of 12.837 × 12.317 Å2 (Figure d), filled by plenty of free water molecules (Figure e). After the removal of free guest solvents, the volume of the effective void, calculated using PLATON, is 26.0% of the unit-cell volume. In complex 1, H2cpds adopts a V-shaped conformation, and the angle between the two carboxylate groups is ca. 90° and can be used effectively for the construction of a polygonal subunit, which enhances the possibility of the formation of a nanotubular framework. From the analyses of the topology network using TOPOS, taking the bimetallic Zn(II) units as 6-connected nodes and the cpds ligands as 3-connected nodes, the 3D structure of compound 1 can be described as a binodal (3,6)-connected network with the Point symbol of (42⋅6)2(44⋅62⋅87⋅102) (Figure f).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 2 is made up of one unique Zn(II) atom, one cpds ligand, and a half bpa ligand (Figure a). Each Zn(II) atom coordinates to four oxygen atoms from four cpds ligands in the equator plane [Zn–O 2.028(9)–2.135(9) Å], and one nitrogen atom of a bpa ligand in the axial position [Zn–N 2.030(11) Å], showing a distorted square-pyramidal coordination environment. Two Zn(II) atoms are bridged by carboxylate groups to give a paddle-wheel shaped with the Zn···Zn distance of 2.974(3) Å. Then, bimetallic Zn(II) units are linked by the bis(bidentate) cpds ligands and bpa ligands to generate a 2D network, in which Zn(II) units bridge cpds ligands to create a curving lattice geometry (Figure b). In particular, the curving lattice is penetrated by the bpa ligand as a “rod” to show a rotaxane-like motif. On the basis of the way of rotaxane-like connection, the two identical 2D networks are interpenetrated with each other to result in a 2-fold interpenetrating structure (Figure c), which is the example of 2-fold 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration. Topologically, the 2D network can be described in Figure d, and the curving lattice acts as a rectangle window in the topological network.

elements.content: Compound 4 exhibits a 2D chiral layer containing three types of single-helical chains and two types of double-stranded helices. As shown in Figure a, the Cd(II) metal center possesses a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry, being linked by four oxygen atoms from two cpds ligands, and three nitrogen atoms from three bpa ligands [Cd–N 2.366(8)–2.370(7) Å, Cd–O 2.353(6)–2.573(7) Å]. All the carboxylic groups of the cpds ligand adopt chelating modes to connect two Cd(II) atoms, and the flexible bpa ligand assumes anti and gauche conformations defined by quite different N–to–N distances, that is those commonly adopted for bpa in the coordination polymers (Figure S1 of the ). In turn, the Cd(II) atoms are bridged by the cpds and bpa to form a 2D layer structure (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
{[Cd(cpds)(bpa)1.5]⋅H2O} n  (4)

Compound 4 exhibits a 2D chiral layer containing three types of single-helical chains and two types of double-stranded helices. As shown in Figure a, the Cd(II) metal center possesses a distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry, being linked by four oxygen atoms from two cpds ligands, and three nitrogen atoms from three bpa ligands [Cd-N 2.366(8)-2.370(7) Å, Cd-O 2.353(6)-2.573(7) Å]. All the carboxylic groups of the cpds ligand adopt chelating modes to connect two Cd(II) atoms, and the flexible bpa ligand assumes anti and gauche conformations defined by quite different N-to-N distances, that is those commonly adopted for bpa in the coordination polymers (Figure S1 of the ). In turn, the Cd(II) atoms are bridged by the cpds and bpa to form a 2D layer structure (Figure b).

elements.content: The structural feature of 4 is that three types of single-helical chains and two types of double-stranded helices coexist in the 2D chiral layer (Figure d). The combination of the twist and the nonlinear flexibility of cpds ligand and different conformations of bpa ligand can result in the different helical chains in 4. At the same time, there exists a special 1D chain constructed by cpds ligand and two conformational bpa ligands in the 2D layer (Figure c), which is comprised of two types of single-helical chains. One is considered to be a chain in which the Cd(II) atoms are linked by the two carboxylate groups of one cpds ligand and two N atoms of a gauche bpa ligand to form an extended helical chain with the pitch of 12.70 Å, donating as (−Cd–cpds–Cd–gauche bpa−) n (code A). The other is made up of Cd(II) atoms and different conformational bpa ligands (anti/gauche) described as (−Cd–anti bpa–Cd–gauche bpa−) n with the pitch of 12.70 Å (code B). In addition, there is another single-helical chain constructed by Cd(II) atoms and gauche bpa ligands (−Cd–gauche bpa−) n with the pitch of 13.79 Å (code C). Besides the single-helical chains, there also exist two types of double-stranded helices in the 2D layer. The first type of double-stranded helix is built from cpds ligand and anti bpa ligand bridged between the Cd(II) centers, and the second one is formed by cpds ligands bridging the Cd(II) catoms (Figure e). Herein, the 2D layer is chiral due to interconnection of same-handed single-helical chains. Furthermore, the different chiral 2D layers are alternating stack with a sequence of ABAB in the crystal (). As a whole, it can afford an achiral structure with centrosymmetric space group (C2/c) in the solid state. Topologically, the 2D helical layer can be regarded as a uninodal five-connected net taking the Cd(II) atoms as five-connected nodes with the Point symbol of (44·66) which is calculated by TOPOS (Figure c).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 5 contains two crystallographically unique Cd(II) atoms with similar coordination environments, described as distorted octahedral geometries (Figure a). The Cd1 center is surrounded by five O atoms from four cpds ligands and one aqua molecule as well as one nitrogen atom from one bpp ligand. Cd2 is ligated by five O atoms from two cpds ligands and three water molecules, and one nitrogen atom of one bpp ligand [Cd–O (2.208(3)–2.372(2) Å), Cd–N (2.282(3)–2.323(3) Å)]. The two Cd(II) atoms are held together by two carboxylate groups and one μ2-H2O (O9), forming a binuclear cadmium unit with the Cd1 ···Cd2 distance of 3.689 Å. Completely deprotonated cpds ligands take two coordination modes: One is a bis(monodentate) coordination mode bridging the binuclear cadmium unit to give the M2L2 type metallocyclic motif. The other adopts a bis(bidentate) coordination mode linking the metallocyclic unit to form a 2D layer (Figure b), which is further linked by bpp ligands to generate a 3D network (Figure c). From the topological point of view, the 3D framework can be simplified to a uninodal five-connected net with (46·64) topology by considering the cadmium dimer as a five-connected node and cpds-bpp mixed ligands as linear bridges (Figure d). Because the void in the single 3D framework is large enough to accommodate other equivalent networks, three independent identical frameworks are interlocked with each other to form a 3-fold interpenetrating network (Figure e). Interestingly, the 3D network is built-up of the hexamer with planar conformation through the strong hydrogen bonds, which are constituted by the oxygen atoms from the free waters with the average O···O distance of 2.812 Å (Figure S3 of the ).

elements.content: The structural discrepancy in complexes 1–5 can be assigned to diverse coordination modes of carboxylate groups and conformations of the cpds ligand. The different coordination modes of cpds ligand in compounds 1–5 are shown in Scheme . In 1 and 2, the carboxylate group of the cpds ligand adopts a (κ1 –κ1)−(κ1 –κ1)−μ4 bridging mode, being linked by Zn(II) atoms to bring on metallocyclic units, supporting the motif of 1D loop chains (Scheme a and b). Differently, the cpds ligand can also afford an N atom to bond the Zn(II) ion in 1, and Zn–N can act as the pillar to extend the framework of 1. In 3, the cpds ligand serves as a (κ2 –κ1)−μ2 coordination mode and connects Zn(II) ions to form a 1D chain (Scheme c). As for 4, the cpds ligand has a (κ2 –κ2)−μ2 bridging fashion to bridge Cd(II) atoms to generate a discrete unit (Scheme d). There are two cpds ligands in 5 with different coordination modes (Scheme b and e). One adopts a (κ1 –κ1)−μ2 bridging mode, and the other is the same as that in compound 2. Then the carboxylate groups bridge two Cd(II) centers to form a binuclear cadmium unit which is connected by cpds ligands to form a 2D layer. The results described above show that the cpds ligand can afford relatively various coordination modes to meet the coordination requirements of the center metal ions. However, for the complexes without N-donor auxiliary ligands, they may favor the formation of lower dimensional structures. In comparison, when the N-donor auxiliary ligands are introduced in the system, the drastic changes are observed from low-dimension to high-dimension in the structures.

Comparison of Structures of Coordination Polymers

Effect of the Flexible Muticarboxylate cpds Ligands

The structural discrepancy in complexes 1-5 can be assigned to diverse coordination modes of carboxylate groups and conformations of the cpds ligand. The different coordination modes of cpds ligand in compounds 1-5 are shown in Scheme . In 1 and 2, the carboxylate group of the cpds ligand adopts a (κ1 -κ1)-(κ1 -κ1)-μ4 bridging mode, being linked by Zn(II) atoms to bring on metallocyclic units, supporting the motif of 1D loop chains (Scheme a and b). Differently, the cpds ligand can also afford an N atom to bond the Zn(II) ion in 1, and Zn-N can act as the pillar to extend the framework of 1. In 3, the cpds ligand serves as a (κ2 -κ1)-μ2 coordination mode and connects Zn(II) ions to form a 1D chain (Scheme c). As for 4, the cpds ligand has a (κ2 -κ2)-μ2 bridging fashion to bridge Cd(II) atoms to generate a discrete unit (Scheme d). There are two cpds ligands in 5 with different coordination modes (Scheme b and e). One adopts a (κ1 -κ1)-μ2 bridging mode, and the other is the same as that in compound 2. Then the carboxylate groups bridge two Cd(II) centers to form a binuclear cadmium unit which is connected by cpds ligands to form a 2D layer. The results described above show that the cpds ligand can afford relatively various coordination modes to meet the coordination requirements of the center metal ions. However, for the complexes without N-donor auxiliary ligands, they may favor the formation of lower dimensional structures. In comparison, when the N-donor auxiliary ligands are introduced in the system, the drastic changes are observed from low-dimension to high-dimension in the structures.

elements.content: Furthermore, compared to rigid carboxylate ligands, the flexible S–S bond in the cpds ligand can rotate freely and the dihedral angle of the two pyridyl rings is changeable in a considerable range (Table S3 of the ). Hence, the flexible bond can adjust the coordination conformations according to the requirement of the metal atoms. In compounds 1 and 2, there are similar C–S–S–C torsion angles in cpds ligand supporting the metallocyclic motif, which afford the space for the 1D metal–organic nanotube in 1 as well as the rotaxane-like motif in 2. In 3, the C–S–S–C torsion angle has a larger and less corrugated nature, so it is not easy to form the interpenetrating structure. The C–S–S–C torsion angle in 4 has a smaller and more corrugated nature, so it is a benefit for the motif of the helical chain. Based on the above-mentioned information, the flexible S–S spacer can allow cpds ligand to bend or rotate when coordinating to metal centers, to lead to many kinds of structures, such as discrete metallocyclic motifs, helical chains, or interpenetrating structures. However, the particular factors to decide the metal complex structure formed by the flexible S–S spacer of cpds ligand have not been well explored so far, and more work is needed to elucidate them.

elements.content: The N-donor auxiliary ligands are good connectors in modulating construction of coordination polymers with novel frameworks. Especially, the derivatives of 4,4′-bipy, such as the flexible rodlike N′,N-donor, can also adopt different conformations through rotation of the −(CH2) n – groups between the two pyridine rings. In compounds 2 and 3, the auxiliary ligands (bpa, bpp) acting as the pillars extend the 1D Zn(II)-cpds coordination chains to result in the formation of the 2D layer. Similarly, bpp could also act as a pillar connector to extend adjacent 2D layers into a 3D framework in compound 5. This means that the dimensionality of the compound can increase through the linkage of bpa and bpp. In addition, a more interesting instance occurs in compound 4: the flexible bpa assumes two different conformations, resulting in enhancing the possibility of the formation of helical chains due to different rotations of the −(CH2)2– groups in bpa. Thus, the conformation of N-containing ligands between coordinating sites can be considered to be a key factor for the helical formation. Although the above-mentioned factors work together to affect the structures of compounds, it is difficult to control and separate them, because all the variable factors cannot be accurately forecasted at this stage. Therefore, comprehensive research is required to be developed and a rational design would be a long-range challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of N-Donor Auxiliary Ligands

The N-donor auxiliary ligands are good connectors in modulating construction of coordination polymers with novel frameworks. Especially, the derivatives of 4,4'-bipy, such as the flexible rodlike N',N-donor, can also adopt different conformations through rotation of the -(CH2) n - groups between the two pyridine rings. In compounds 2 and 3, the auxiliary ligands (bpa, bpp) acting as the pillars extend the 1D Zn(II)-cpds coordination chains to result in the formation of the 2D layer. Similarly, bpp could also act as a pillar connector to extend adjacent 2D layers into a 3D framework in compound 5. This means that the dimensionality of the compound can increase through the linkage of bpa and bpp. In addition, a more interesting instance occurs in compound 4: the flexible bpa assumes two different conformations, resulting in enhancing the possibility of the formation of helical chains due to different rotations of the -(CH2)2- groups in bpa. Thus, the conformation of N-containing ligands between coordinating sites can be considered to be a key factor for the helical formation. Although the above-mentioned factors work together to affect the structures of compounds, it is difficult to control and separate them, because all the variable factors cannot be accurately forecasted at this stage. Therefore, comprehensive research is required to be developed and a rational design would be a long-range challenge.

elements.content: XRPD experiments were carried out on 1–5 in order to establish their crystalline phase purity. As shown in the XRPD patterns (Figure S4 of the ), the PXRD patterns of bulk samples 1–5 are consistent with the simulated patterns based on the single crystal data, indicating the presence of mainly one crystalline phase in the corresponding coordination polymers 1–5.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD Patterns and Thermal Stability Analyses

XRPD experiments were carried out on 1-5 in order to establish their crystalline phase purity. As shown in the XRPD patterns (Figure S4 of the ), the PXRD patterns of bulk samples 1-5 are consistent with the simulated patterns based on the single crystal data, indicating the presence of mainly one crystalline phase in the corresponding coordination polymers 1-5.

elements.content: To identify the thermal stabilities of these complexes, the TGA measurements were carried out (Figure ). In 1, the result shows a first major weight loss equal to 4.33%, before 200 °C, ascribed to the release of all free water molecules (calcd 4.62%). So, the framework is stable up to 200 °C, at which point the removal of organic ligands can ensue. Compounds 2–3 can keep the stabilization until 230 and 270 °C because there is almost no mass loss, and then the structures collapse slowly. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 17.25%, 14.89%; calcd 17.55%, 14.28%). The first weight loss in compound 4 occurs in the range 40–160 °C, implying removal of the free water molecules (obsd 2.77%, calcd 2.52%), leaving a framework of [Cd(cpds)(bpa)1.5]. And then the framework begins to decompose at 190 °C. As for 5, there is a weight loss of 10.28% (calcd 10.85%) in the range of 33–196 °C, revealing the exclusion of all water molecules. Compound 5 can keep the stabilization of the framework until 200 °C. Then, the decomposition of the remaining substance finished at 800 °C. Finally, the residue is CdO (obsd 21.69%, calcd 22.11%).
elements.clean_text: To identify the thermal stabilities of these complexes, the TGA measurements were carried out (Figure ). So, the framework is stable up to 200 °C, at which point the removal of organic ligands can ensue. elements.content: In principle, the stability of an open structure cannot be solely determined from the TGA measurement, since it may collapse without a notable change in weight. To further test the stability of the microporous framework of 1, we examined the samples by XRPD after the removal of free guest solvents (Figure S4 of the ). The fully evacuated sample of 1 was found to be unchanged, at least up to 200 °C, indicating that the microporous framework of 1 can remain stable after the loss of guest water molecules.

elements.content: Organic–inorganic coordination polymers, especially those with d10 metal centers, have been investigated for their fluorescent properties and potential applications as fluorescent-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Therefore, the photoluminescence properties of 1–5 and free ligands (H2cpds) were studied in the solid state (Figure ). Intense emission bands are observed at 395 nm and 450 nm (λex = 280 nm) for H2cpds, which can be assigned to the ligand-centered electronic transitions, that is, the π* → n or π* → π electronic transitions. Compound 1 shows one main peak at 520 nm upon excitation at 280 nm, and the bimodal emissions are also observed at 462 and 522 nm for 2 and at 465 and 519 nm for 3. Compared with the free H2cpds, the main peaks in 1, 2, and 3 are red-shifted, which may result from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Comparing the emissions of 2 and 3, the stronger peak in compound 1 can be tentatively ascribed to the enhancement of structural rigidity due to the existence of a Zn–N bond. Furthermore, compounds 4 and 5 exhibit bimodal emission at 412 and 460 nm for 4 and at 394 and 452 nm for 5 upon excitation at 280 nm, respectively, which are similar to those of H2cpds. Together with the electronic structures of cpds after coordination to Cd(II) ions and the π–π conjugations, the emission origin of 4 and 5 is probably due to the coordination of the ligands. The difference in emission properties between 1–5 is due to the rigidity difference of their host frameworks as well as the coordination diversity of metal ions. Generally speaking, the weak luminescences based on Zn(II)/Cd(II)-cpds coordination polymers are always observed, and more work is needed to elucidate the real nature of emission.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Organic-inorganic coordination polymers, especially those with d10 metal centers, have been investigated for their fluorescent properties and potential applications as fluorescent-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs). Therefore, the photoluminescence properties of 1-5 and free ligands (H2cpds) were studied in the solid state (Figure ). Intense emission bands are observed at 395 nm and 450 nm (λex = 280 nm) for H2cpds, which can be assigned to the ligand-centered electronic transitions, that is, the π* → n or π* → π electronic transitions. Compound 1 shows one main peak at 520 nm upon excitation at 280 nm, and the bimodal emissions are also observed at 462 and 522 nm for 2 and at 465 and 519 nm for 3. Compared with the free H2cpds, the main peaks in 1, 2, and 3 are red-shifted, which may result from ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Comparing the emissions of 2 and 3, the stronger peak in compound 1 can be tentatively ascribed to the enhancement of structural rigidity due to the existence of a Zn-N bond. Furthermore, compounds 4 and 5 exhibit bimodal emission at 412 and 460 nm for 4 and at 394 and 452 nm for 5 upon excitation at 280 nm, respectively, which are similar to those of H2cpds. Together with the electronic structures of cpds after coordination to Cd(II) ions and the π-π conjugations, the emission origin of 4 and 5 is probably due to the coordination of the ligands. The difference in emission properties between 1-5 is due to the rigidity difference of their host frameworks as well as the coordination diversity of metal ions. Generally speaking, the weak luminescences based on Zn(II)/Cd(II)-cpds coordination polymers are always observed, and more work is needed to elucidate the real nature of emission.

elements.content: In conclusion, five novel complexes have been prepared based on Zn(II)/Cd(II) metals, the disulfide derivative of carboxylate (H2cpds), and flexible rodlike N,N′-donor ligands. Complexes 2–4 all exhibit 2D layer structures, in which 2 displays a 2-fold 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration framework and 3 is a 2D 44 gridlike layer. Compound 4 contains two kinds of 2D chiral layers, which are composed of three types of single-helical chains and two types of double-stranded helices. Three high-dimensional complexes (3D) with a microporous network containing a 1D metal–organic nanotube for 1 and a 3-fold interpenetrating network with (4664) topology for 5 are observed. Complexes 1–5 display various coordination motifs due to different conformations, and coordination modes of the H2cpds ligand; at the same time, the effect of the auxiliary ligands plays important roles in the construction of extended supramolecular networks. Simultaneously, not only is the cpds ligand a simple multicarboxylate ligand, but it can also afford an N atom to bond the metals, which is first observed in M-cpds complexes. Finally, these interesting observations prompt us to further research the rational synthetic strategy to obtain new crystalline materials with special properties and structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, five novel complexes have been prepared based on Zn(II)/Cd(II) metals, the disulfide derivative of carboxylate (H2cpds), and flexible rodlike N,N'-donor ligands. Complexes 2-4 all exhibit 2D layer structures, in which 2 displays a 2-fold 2D → 2D parallel interpenetration framework and 3 is a 2D 44 gridlike layer. Compound 4 contains two kinds of 2D chiral layers, which are composed of three types of single-helical chains and two types of double-stranded helices. Three high-dimensional complexes (3D) with a microporous network containing a 1D metal-organic nanotube for 1 and a 3-fold interpenetrating network with (4664) topology for 5 are observed. Complexes 1-5 display various coordination motifs due to different conformations, and coordination modes of the H2cpds ligand; at the same time, the effect of the auxiliary ligands plays important roles in the construction of extended supramolecular networks. Simultaneously, not only is the cpds ligand a simple multicarboxylate ligand, but it can also afford an N atom to bond the metals, which is first observed in M-cpds complexes. Finally, these interesting observations prompt us to further research the rational synthetic strategy to obtain new crystalline materials with special properties and structures.
